description:
Edhazardia aedis USNM 41457 is a species of protozoan parasite that infects the mosquito Aedes aegypti, a common vector of diseases such as dengue, Zika, and chikungunya. This single-celled organism is classified under the phylum Apicomplexa, and it is known to reside within the fat body tissues of the mosquito host.

The life cycle of Edhazardia aedis involves the development of various life stages, including meronts, gamonts, and oocysts, which are crucial for the parasite's reproduction and transmission. The infection typically occurs when the mosquito larvae ingest the parasite's oocysts, which then develop and multiply within the mosquito's tissues.

Edhazardia aedis has been studied as a potential biological control agent against Aedes aegypti mosquitoes, as its presence has been shown to reduce the lifespan and fecundity of the mosquito host, potentially impacting disease transmission. Further research is ongoing to explore the ecological and epidemiological implications of this host-parasite relationship.
